field.name: Aerospace & Defense
field.description: Manufacturing of aircraft, spacecraft, missiles, defense systems, and related components including avionics, propulsion systems, and maintenance/repair/overhaul (MRO) operations.

problems.title: Critical MRO Engine Maintenance Capacity Shortage Threatens Commercial Aviation Fleet Availability
problems.description: The aerospace maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) industry faces a severe capacity crisis that threatens the operational readiness of the global commercial aviation fleet. Aircraft engine MRO demand is projected to peak in 2026 and remain constrained through the end of the decade. If MRO capacity continues to grow on its current trajectory, demand for shop visits will exceed supply by more than 17% by decade's end. This crisis stems from multiple converging factors: shop visits deferred during the COVID-19 pandemic created significant pent-up demand; newer generation CFM International LEAP engines and especially Pratt & Whitney GTF engines are requiring repairs in much greater numbers than anticipated due to issues including powder metal contamination; and the supply of used serviceable materials is constrained as airlines delay retiring legacy aircraft. The consequences include grounded aircraft, reduced flight schedules, higher maintenance costs, and pressure on airline profitability. Airlines are being forced to keep aging Boeing 737NG and Airbus A320ceo models in service longer, which increases complexity and turnaround times for MRO providers.
problems.summary: Aircraft engine MRO demand will exceed capacity by 17%+ through 2030, driven by pandemic deferrals, new engine reliability issues, and parts shortages, threatening fleet availability.

barriers: Long lead time for technician training
Engine design issues requiring engineering fixes

neglectedness.activeResearchers: Major consulting firms, OEMs, airlines actively engaged
neglectedness.fundingLevel: High - $1.88B digital MRO market growing at 12.8% CAGR

Airlines delaying retirement of legacy aircraft reduces supply of used serviceable materials

Shortage of skilled aviation maintenance technicians

consequences.description: Airlines forced to ground aircraft awaiting engine maintenance
Flight schedule reductions and route cancellations

Increased ticket prices passed to consumers

problems.title: Critical Shortage of Skilled Aviation Maintenance Technicians Threatens Industry Safety and Capacity
problems.description: The aerospace and defense industry faces a severe and worsening shortage of skilled maintenance technicians that threatens both operational capacity and safety standards. Despite rising technician certifications, projections show commercial aviation will have 10% fewer certified mechanics than needed by 2025, with the gap expected to widen. This workforce crisis is driven by multiple factors: an aging workforce with a wave of retirements, insufficient pipeline of new entrants to aviation maintenance careers, competition from other industries for technical talent, and the increasing complexity of modern aircraft requiring more specialized skills. The shortage is particularly acute for specialized roles involving composite materials, advanced avionics, and new propulsion technologies. MRO providers struggle to recruit and retain qualified personnel, leading to extended turnaround times, quality concerns, and increased costs. The problem is compounded by the need to upskill existing workers for advanced technologies including AI-based diagnostic systems, digital twins, and automated inspection tools.
problems.summary: Aviation will have 10% fewer certified mechanics than needed, driven by retirements, insufficient new entrants, and increasing skill requirements for advanced aircraft technologies.

barriers: Long training and certification timelines (2-4 years)
Competition from other industries for technical talent
Perception issues making aviation maintenance less attractive to youth
Geographic mismatches between workforce and job locations

problems.title: Defense Industrial Base Cybersecurity Vulnerabilities Expose National Security to Supply Chain Attacks
problems.description: The defense industrial base faces severe cybersecurity vulnerabilities that pose significant risks to national security. Supply chain cybersecurity attacks have increased by 431% since 2021, with manufacturing seeing a 71% surge in threat actor activity between 2024 and early 2025, involving 29 distinct threat groups. State-sponsored attackers increasingly target defense contractors using zero-day exploits and advanced persistent threats (APTs), often exploiting smaller, less sophisticated third-party suppliers as vectors to access larger defense contractors. The defense supply chain's vast network of third-party stakeholders creates multiple attack surfaces. Legacy operational technology (OT) systems in manufacturing were never designed for cybersecurity and remain under-monitored, unpatched, and unsegmented. IoT devices in supply chains typically experience attack attempts within minutes of connecting to the internet. Research indicates that private sector cybersecurity investment may be insufficient to meet national security needs, as commercial incentives don't align with defense requirements. The Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC) 2.0 now affects over 300,000 companies but compliance remains challenging, particularly for small and medium suppliers.
problems.summary: Supply chain cyberattacks up 431% since 2021, with state actors targeting 300,000+ defense suppliers through legacy OT systems and third-party vulnerabilities.

barriers: Vast attack surface across complex supply chains
Legacy OT systems difficult to secure
Small suppliers lack resources for robust cybersecurity
Evolving threat landscape with state-sponsored actors
Misaligned incentives between commercial and national security needs

neglectedness.fundingLevel: High - significant government and private investment

rootCauses.description: Legacy OT systems never designed for cybersecurity remain unpatched and unsegmented
Vast third-party supplier network with inconsistent security practices
State-sponsored threat actors with sophisticated capabilities and resources
Private sector underinvestment in cybersecurity relative to national security needs
Rapid IoT adoption without adequate security measures

consequences.description: Theft of classified and sensitive defense technology data
Potential sabotage of defense manufacturing systems
Loss of competitive advantage to adversary nations
Increased compliance costs for defense suppliers

problems.title: Aerospace Supply Chain Spare Parts Shortages Causing Extended Aircraft Downtime and Operational Disruptions
problems.description: Supply chain challenges for aerospace spare parts availability have emerged as the top issue facing the aviation maintenance industry. Deferred aircraft deliveries mean airlines continue to rely on aging fleets requiring servicing with greater complexity and longer turnaround times. The lack of spare parts contributes to extended shop visits, while delays in retiring legacy aircraft (particularly Boeing 737NG and Airbus A320ceo models) constrain the supply of used serviceable materials. The aerospace supply chain faces multiple compounding pressures: semiconductor shortages affecting avionics components, raw material constraints for titanium and specialty alloys, concentration of critical component suppliers, and logistics disruptions. Component lead times have extended significantly, with some parts requiring 12-18 months advance ordering. Airlines and MRO providers must maintain larger safety stock inventories, tying up capital and warehouse space. The globalization of aerospace manufacturing has created complex multi-tier supply chains vulnerable to disruption at any point, while single-source dependencies for critical components create systemic risks.
problems.summary: Spare parts shortages now top aviation maintenance challenges, with extended lead times, depleted used serviceable materials, and multi-tier supply chain vulnerabilities.

barriers: Long certification cycles for alternative suppliers

rootCauses.description: Global supply chain disruptions from pandemic aftereffects and geopolitical tensions
Deferred aircraft retirements depleting used serviceable materials pool
Semiconductor and raw material shortages affecting component production
Concentration of suppliers creating single points of failure

consequences.description: Extended aircraft turnaround times at MRO facilities
Increased parts costs and inventory carrying expenses
Aircraft grounded awaiting parts
Potential safety risks from parts substitution pressure

problems.title: Aerospace Quality Certification Compliance Burden Strains Manufacturers and Supply Chain Partners
problems.description: The aerospace industry operates under complex and evolving regulatory requirements that create significant compliance burdens for manufacturers and suppliers. Companies must navigate multiple overlapping certification frameworks including AS9100 (quality management), NADCAP (special processes), and various airworthiness authorities (FAA, EASA). The globalization of aerospace manufacturing has complicated compliance as organizations face diverse regional requirements and expectations. Achieving and maintaining certifications requires substantial investment in quality management systems, documentation, audits, and continuous improvement programs. Small and medium suppliers face particular challenges given limited resources. The rigorous certification requirements, while essential for safety, create barriers to entry, extend development timelines, and increase costs. Supply chain quality assurance is complicated by multi-tier supplier networks spanning the globe, while counterfeit parts prevention (governed by standards like AS5553A) requires extensive traceability systems. The certification landscape continues to evolve, requiring organizations to continuously adapt their quality systems.
problems.summary: Aerospace manufacturers face complex, overlapping certification requirements (AS9100, NADCAP) that strain resources, extend timelines, and create barriers especially for smaller suppliers.

barriers: Multiple regulatory jurisdictions with different requirements

rootCauses.description: Multiple regulatory authorities with overlapping but distinct requirements
Globalization creating need to meet diverse regional standards
Continuous evolution of standards in response to incidents and technology changes
Complex multi-tier supply chains requiring quality assurance at each level

consequences.description: Significant investment required for certification and maintenance
Extended development and qualification timelines
Barrier to entry for potential new suppliers
Resource diversion from innovation to compliance

problems.title: Aerospace Industry Ransomware and Cyberattack Surge Disrupts Operations and Threatens Data Security
problems.description: The aerospace industry is experiencing a dramatic surge in ransomware and cyberattacks that disrupt operations and threaten sensitive data. Thales data reveals a 600% increase in ransomware incidents between 2024 and 2025. A notable example occurred in September 2025 when a cyberattack disrupted check-in systems at major European airports including Brussels, London, and Berlin. These attacks target the full aerospace ecosystem including airlines, airports, MRO providers, and manufacturers. The convergence of IT and OT systems in modern aerospace operations creates expanded attack surfaces, while the interconnected nature of airline and airport systems means breaches can cascade rapidly. Aerospace organizations hold valuable targets including passenger data, proprietary designs, flight operations systems, and supply chain information. Many organizations have legacy systems with inadequate security, and the industry's reliance on third-party vendors and complex supply chains creates multiple potential entry points for attackers. The financial and operational impacts of successful attacks are severe, including operational shutdowns, data theft, ransom payments, regulatory penalties, and reputational damage.
problems.summary: Ransomware attacks on aerospace increased 600% from 2024-2025, with incidents disrupting major airports and threatening the interconnected airline/airport ecosystem.

problems.title: Digital Twin and AI Integration Barriers Slow Aerospace Manufacturing Modernization
problems.description: Despite significant potential, the aerospace industry faces substantial barriers to adopting digital twin technology and AI-based manufacturing solutions. While digital twins promise to revolutionize aircraft design, manufacturing, and maintenance through virtual replicas enabling simulation, optimization, and predictive analytics, implementation challenges have slowed progress. By 2026, agentic AI is expected to progress from pilot projects to scaled deployments, but achieving this transition requires overcoming significant hurdles. Key barriers include: data integration challenges across disparate legacy systems; lack of standardized data formats and interoperability; high implementation costs requiring significant upfront investment; workforce skill gaps in data science and AI; cybersecurity concerns about digital models of critical systems; organizational resistance to new ways of working; and regulatory uncertainty around AI-based decision making in safety-critical applications. The digital aerospace MRO market is projected to grow from $1.02 billion in 2025 to $1.88 billion by 2030, but realizing this potential requires addressing these adoption barriers.
problems.summary: Aerospace digital twin and AI adoption faces barriers including legacy system integration, data standardization, skills gaps, and regulatory uncertainty despite $1.88B market potential.

barriers: Regulatory uncertainty for AI in safety-critical applications

rootCauses.description: Disparate legacy systems with incompatible data formats
High upfront investment requirements with uncertain ROI timelines
Shortage of personnel with digital twin and AI expertise
Unclear regulatory frameworks for AI in safety-critical decisions

consequences.description: Slower productivity improvements compared to potential
Competitive disadvantage versus more digitally mature competitors
Missed opportunities for predictive maintenance benefits

problems.title: Counterfeit Aerospace Parts Infiltration Threatens Aviation Safety and Supply Chain Integrity
problems.description: The aerospace industry faces an ongoing challenge with counterfeit and substandard parts infiltrating supply chains, posing serious safety risks and quality concerns. ISO Aerospace Standard AS5553A was instituted specifically to check the global supply chain for counterfeit parts, yet the problem persists. Counterfeit parts range from simple fasteners to complex electronics, and may include parts with falsified documentation, substandard materials, or improper manufacturing processes. The globalization of aerospace supply chains has complicated detection efforts, with multi-tier supplier networks spanning numerous countries. Parts may pass through multiple distributors before reaching end users, creating opportunities for counterfeits to enter the legitimate supply chain. Detection requires extensive traceability systems, material testing, and documentation verification. The consequences of counterfeit parts range from increased maintenance costs and operational disruptions to catastrophic safety failures. Blockchain and other traceability technologies are emerging as potential solutions, but widespread adoption remains limited. Small and medium suppliers may lack resources for comprehensive parts authentication programs.
problems.summary: Counterfeit parts continue infiltrating aerospace supply chains despite AS5553A standards, with globalized multi-tier networks complicating detection and threatening safety.

barriers: Complex global supply chains with multiple tiers

rootCauses.description: Complex multi-tier global supply chains creating opacity
Economic incentives for counterfeiting given high component values
Inconsistent enforcement across international jurisdictions
Sophisticated counterfeiting techniques including falsified documentation

consequences.description: Potential catastrophic safety failures from part failures
Increased maintenance costs and unplanned repairs
Erosion of trust in supply chain integrity
Regulatory penalties and liability exposure

problems.title: New Generation Aircraft Engine Reliability Issues Drive Unplanned Maintenance and Fleet Disruptions
problems.description: Newer generation commercial aircraft engines, specifically CFM International LEAP and Pratt & Whitney GTF (Geared Turbofan) engines, are experiencing reliability issues that require repairs in much greater numbers than originally anticipated. The GTF engines in particular have been affected by issues including powder metal contamination in high-pressure turbine disks, necessitating accelerated inspections and removals across the global fleet. These problems have caused significant operational disruptions for airlines operating Airbus A320neo and A220 aircraft. The unexpected maintenance requirements strain an already capacity-constrained MRO network, extend aircraft downtime, and impact airline scheduling and profitability. Engine manufacturers are working on engineering solutions and accelerating parts production, but the fixes require time to develop, certify, and implement. Airlines face difficult decisions about fleet utilization, with some aircraft grounded or operating under restrictions pending inspections. The situation highlights challenges in new engine program maturity and the tension between fuel efficiency innovations and long-term reliability.
problems.summary: LEAP and GTF next-gen engines require repairs far exceeding forecasts due to powder metal contamination and other issues, straining MRO capacity and grounding aircraft.

affectedPopulation.estimate: Airlines operating A320neo, A220, and 737 MAX fleets

barriers: Engineering fixes require development and certification time

problems.title: Aging Aircraft Fleet Extension Increases Maintenance Complexity and Operational Risk
problems.description: Airlines globally are extending the operational life of aging aircraft fleets, particularly Boeing 737NG and Airbus A320ceo models, due to new aircraft delivery delays and economic pressures. This fleet extension strategy creates significant challenges for the maintenance ecosystem and introduces operational risks. Older aircraft require servicing involving greater complexity and longer turnaround times, with structural fatigue, corrosion, and systems degradation requiring more intensive inspection and repair. The extension of legacy fleets also impacts the supply of used serviceable materials, as parts that would normally enter the secondary market through aircraft retirements remain in service. Maintenance documentation for older aircraft may be less digitized, complicating work planning and execution. Workforce expertise in older aircraft types becomes increasingly valuable but scarce as technicians retire. Airlines must balance the economics of continued operation against the rising maintenance costs and potential safety implications of operating aging aircraft beyond their originally anticipated service lives.
problems.summary: Airlines extending 737NG and A320ceo operations due to delivery delays face increased maintenance complexity, longer turnarounds, and depleted used parts supply.

barriers: New aircraft delivery delays outside airline control
Limited MRO capacity for complex heavy maintenance
Declining expertise in legacy aircraft types

neglectedness.fundingLevel: Moderate - airlines investing in fleet maintenance

consequences.description: Increased maintenance costs per flight hour
